This question is more interesting than my first impression: - 0 out of 5 Margaret Atwood Novels published since 2005 made the top 5 (so not even close to #1) of any NYT bestseller list published online. However, Handmaid's Tale has had incredible success long after it was first published.
-Stephen King's new book comes out the same day (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/890730 ). King's baseline to reach #1 is 91%, or 10 out of 11 novels published since 2014. When "Sleeping Beauties" came out, King's classic "It" ranked above Handmaid's Tale on the paperback best seller list for a few weeks. Interestingly, all 11 recent Stephen King novels I looked at peaked in the 3rd week after publication and none reached #1 in the first two weeks after they came out. So this suggests to me that if The Testaments is going to be #1 it will be in week 1 or 2, highly likely to be ranked behind Stephen King's new book in week 3. Raising slightly above crowd, which I think is bordering on overconfidence already, and will revise in week 1 after The Testaments is published at the latest.

Margaret Atwood has 11 books in the New York Times bestseller database: Bodily Harm (1981), THE HANDMAID'S TALE (1985), Alias Grace (1996), The Blind Assassin (2000), Oryx and Crake (2003), Moral Disorder and Other Stories (2006),  The Year of the Flood (2009), MaddAddam (2013), The Heart Goes Last (2015), Angel Catbird (2016), and Hag-Seed (2016). A list on Wikipedia of her novels: The Edible Woman (1969), Surfacing (1972), Lady Oracle (1976), Life Before Man (1979), *Bodily Harm (1981), *The Handmaid's Tale (1985), Cat's Eye (1988), The Robber Bride (1993), *Alias Grace (1996), *The Blind Assassin (2000), *Oryx and Crake (2003), The Penelopiad (2005), *The Year of the Flood (2009), *MaddAddam (2013), *The Heart Goes Last (2015), *Hag-Seed (2016), and the book in question, The Testaments (2019).[1] (Starred are on the list). Baseline, if you wanted to use all her novels would be 9/16 or 56%. It probably makes sense to drop the first four, which gives us 9/12 or 75% as a floor prediction. She's made the list for every novel but one for the last +20 years, so 7/8 or 88%. And, since Trump got into office, The Handmaiden's Tale spent something like 100 weeks on the list, and this is a sequel. This is being published on September 10th. It's probably already a bestseller based on pre-orders. I think we can safely call this one 100%.  [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Margaret_Atwood#Novels_2
